In Depth version:

Hmm. Let's start with the big white elephant in the room. Is this pay to win? No, it's pay to convenience.

reviewText:
Tera was released in May 2012, and it went Free To Play in February 2013.

The game has stood the test of time, and still has a decent-sized, dedicated player base. It is also frequented by many players who MMO hop looking for anything free to entertain them. That's what I used to do, until Tera got me hooked.

Tera initially had 8 classes, and has since added two new classes, and had an official expansion (Fate of Arun) on top of multiple content updates (Fane of Kaprima, Wonderholme, Wounded World, etc.)

The biggest strength of Tera and what sets it apart from other MMOs is its action combat.  There's no tab-targeting here, most skills require you to understand their hitboxes in order to land (the exception being some lock-on skills). Every class has a reticle in the middle of your screen so you know where you are aiming.

Tera runs in Unreal Engine 3, but the developers did a fantastic job to create the vibrant fantasy world of Arborea. The first time I entered Heartwood around level 40, it totally blew me away with how beautiful it was.

The developer of Tera, Bluehole Studios, is based in South Korea - and Tera is distributed with many publishers around the world. However, for this version of Tera (NA Tera), one of the best parts about Tera is the publisher, En Masse Entertainment. They do a good job of listening to the feedback of their players and adjusting the game to keep everything as balanced as possible.

A lot of current players get asked the question It Tera worth it? Is it worth my time having already been released for so long?" I highly recommend everyone spend a little time playing Tera
date: it is worth your time.\n\n[edit to fix typo - Fane of Kaprima]"

reviewText:
TERA is:
NOT Pay2Win
NOT stiff or clunky
Fun
FREE
Easy to get into
Balanced (at least as far as PVE goes)

But really, The game's good. Unlike other MMOs like say, WoW where you can pump stats  and become practically untouchable as you stand still while the game dictates whether you dodge or not. You actually have to evade attacks yourself. The stats only control your damage output and some damage mitigation as well as resistance to knockdown (your worst enemy for any class). You want an XP boost? either get it from the game store OR the in game vendor that takes federation bills, which you get 5 of each day.

A few things about certain classes:

BERSERKER- If you're making a Berserker, fighting BAMs will be the most annoying thing to deal with at early levels, since you'll spend most of the fight blocking, though it depends how fast and mobile the particular BAM is, but yeah, its better to team up with someone that can distract the BAM so you can get the maximum damage out (Berserkers have the highest single hit burst damage in the game, properly specced out you can take a solid chunk out of a boss's health bar, compared to the steady bits going away when the entire group's beating on it. Also, if all goes right, bring someone to tears in PVP). I say this because zerkers lack real mobility like the other classes have, so you'll notice it takes longer to down a BAM solo,  compared to other classes.

WARRIOR- If you want a challenge, try learning to be an evasive tank on Warrior. Their offense is excellent, I'd even say easy, but trying to tank when you know the boss/room full of minions can blow you up since you're wearing leather, plus dishing out damage is a nice balancing act.

MYSTIC- send pet, use damage spells, pet dies, put enemy to sleep, resummon pet and repeat. Personally I only find this class fun in dungeons since you can't use the tanking pet in there (unless you're soloing a group dungeon), it screws up the Tank's mojo and also pulls extra aggro when you're trying to be sneaky.

GUNNER- I'd have to say this is the easiest class in the game. You get dodge on a 5 second timer that has a chance to not trigger the cooldown timer, plus a rocket jump for extra mobility, a grenade that stuns, a bot that heals you and a proximity turret. Believe me, this is the most newbie friendly class in the game. and one of the few classes that can take advantage of more damage from behind" bonuses when standing right in front of the enemy.....When you see their moveset
date: you'll see what I'm talking about.\n\nREAPER- The stunlock king. You get 3 stuns
hoursPlayed: an attack that spaces you quite a ways away from the target AND the ability to cheat death. So unless you're going after some really mobile and hard hitting BAMs you can go from fight to fight with little to no breaks in between.\n\n*haven't tried archer

reviewText:
Best F2P model I've ever seen. Absolutely gorgeous graphics and art design. Combat is much more satisfying than any MMO I've played. Great fun classes.

The whole Elin obsession thing is still pretty weird to me but to each his own since I do love playing badass female characters, I just don't see what the Elin appeal is, I think the majority of it is players just want to have a badass cutsy character.

The story to me is pretty bad but I've been somewhat spoiled coming from SWtOR where they actuall tell you the story. Characters that seem important seem to pop up out of nowhere and there is little in the way of character development. Although when you get into the overall story of fighting the war it is pretty cool but smaller side things are confusing, cutscenes are LESS than mediocre.
Missions and quest are equally bad, 90% kill fetch quests, although the kill quests are somewhat offset by the combat being so much fun. Crafting is overly complicated, tedious, time consuming and boring, you literally cant do ANYTHING while crafting but stare at your screen, may as well alt tab out for about 10 minutes. however again this is offset somewhat by the fact that you can craft end-game gear and make VERY good money from crafting.

The subscription model is just OK, could be a ton better but it definately has it's perks especially during leveling.
I haven't really run into a great number of toxic players and most times I've been matched in a dungeon players have been polite and helpful, the general chat is of couse garbage, haven't been in an MMO yet where it hasen't been, but this  is typically a small percentage of morons who have nothing better to do than spit vomit in chat, the people actually playing the game don't bother.

Constant news and stream from the publisher and the devs seem ok at keeping up with the community, not 100% but better than some games I've played.

All said and done I'd give it a 8/10 fun game and awesome to look at, great combat. Some tedious things in the game that seem they could be easily improved on though.

reviewerDisplayName: W r a i t h
reviewText:
TERA has exactly what you would expect from a Korean MMORPG, which is not really a bad thing depending on your preferences of course.

1. Great combat system. Yes, the famous true combat system that the TERA developers and fanbase brag about all the time. Is it good? Well, yes, it's the best in its class (at least until other KMMOs like Black Desert step in and try to dethrone it from the NA market). Other MMOs only try to match TERA fluid combat system. The only other games I know of that exist right now that can even come close are RaiderZ (combat is the only thing going for that) and C9. So what is the system? No tab-targetting, aimed attacked, combos, dodging, fluid transitions between skills, ooohhhhh it's really something you have to try for yourself.

2. Lots of grinding. Well, it's a Korean MMO after all and where would a Korean MMO be without lots of farming and grinding. That's definitely something that puts the combat system to the test now isn't it? Something I really like about TERA is the enemy variety within a single area. You'll have enemies where you'll be bursting down, then dodging while waiting for cooldowns just to burst again moments later.  You'll have enemies you can beat in only one string of skills. There's a third kind which dies in generally one hit. REALLY, JUST ONE HIT!!!!!! Considering nowadays most MMOs consist of you repeatedly ripping into enemies while fun numbers appear of their heads over and over until they finally die and you're left exhausted and bored,  grinding in TERA is a breath of fresh air. So farm to your hearts content, because it's way better than in most games.

3. Waifus? Well again, Korean MMO, so obviously you'll be trying to make the sexiest character possible. There's some presets as always, but then comes the sliders for adjusting ears and nose bridges and mouth position and all that stuff you either love or dread at the start of an MMO. Essentially, there's decent customization for your waifu making pleasure. Lots of armor sets, again focused towards making waifus which I'm sure you would have expected by now.

4. Cash shop are usually handled moderately well in most Korean MMOs, at least the ones that I've played (except for the post-2010 p2w deathtrap known as Maplestory among others). Lots of cosmetics, you know, to enhance the waifu experience of course. You could become an elite member where you pay a fee and get more XP and discounts at the EMP store if you want, but that's not anything p2w. Leveling isn't that hard that this XP boosts become unfair, and 2x XP events aren't that uncommon either. They also sell the usual, character slots, gender changes, facial changes, some keys to open chests (praying to RNGesus for days), mounts, pets. But nothing bad nothing to ruin any f2p players experiences.

5. PvE vs. PvP server: The PvE server is your traditional MMO server where you aren't beating noobs to a pulp as they try to do quests. You can play in PvP matches separately from all the PvE content just like your typical MMO. PvP servers, watch out noobs because some people just like it best when your precious waifu is dead on the floor while they laugh and wait for more noobs come. Yeah, you can see how that's turning out. It's a real fun and different experience worth checking out once you've hit max level in a PvE server or think you're good enough to meet the challenge.

6. Endgame content? Well, they have more quests, PvP, dungeons, grinding for end game gear, the usual stuff. Enough content to keep players going but I won't go in-depth on that mainly because I never focus on doing endgame content in MMOs aside from dungeons and a bit of PvP from time to time. They have a great little guide on endgame content over on the TERA website for you.

7. Economy-wise, I don' think making money is too difficult in TERA. Even at early levels, you'll be finding items you can sell for like 100 gold (uses the copper, silver, gold currency system) at the brokerage (basically an auction house, trading post, nothing new here). You'll easily be able to afford anything you require at your level until you start looking for rarer items. You think 100 gold is a lot? Well, when a guy walks around with like 50,000 gold then you'll see how insignificant your stash is. However, you'll never feel like you're ever lacking funds, until you start looking for rarer stuff.

reviewText:
Free MMO - so try it out.
If you are a fan of World of Warcraft you will most likely like this game too.
Much like World of Warcraft you take quests from quest givers and participate in guilds (if you chose)  and party raids and dungeons.
You can design your character and how it looks with good detail.
Very good graphics and controls for movement.
You can team with others to finish quests. Or play solo - it is your choice.
Very enjoyable game.

reviewText:
TERA isn't a World of Warcraft killer, but it's not just another World of Warcraft ripoff, either. It's more like a World of Warcraft supplement, or a World of Warcraft successor: If you enjoy WoW and are up for a change of pace, TERA will be perfect for you. Most of it will feel immediately familiar, but there are enough changes to keep you interested, and all of the adjustments are for the better. It's basically Saint's Row to WoW's Grand Theft Auto. You should never forget where it came from, but it's a step in the right direction.

Nearly all the basic infrastructure here is stolen directly from World of Warcraft. You're given a constant barrage of quests to accomplish—kill this, fetch that—and in the process you explore new areas one by one. You can team up with other players to take on dungeons and bosses that are too powerful for you. You collect new gear and sell your old stuff. You craft items you can't find. Even the color palette, the creature design, and the basic landscaping of the world have a distinctly Warcraftian feel to them, and the quest names are rife with whimsical pop culture references.

But there are some real differences, too, and the first and most important is the combat. All the clunkiness of fighting in World of Warcraft—and most other MMOs, for that matter—is gone, replaced by an action-based system that controls like an FPS. You can't just select a nearby enemy and tell your character to attack; instead, you have to place your crosshairs over your foe and press an action button. In addition, each character comes with a simple defensive maneuver you can use to avoid damage—and, of course, as you progress through the game you'll unlock plenty of extra spells and moves.

The precise mechanisms of combat will depend on which class you choose at the game's outset. I've played with archer, gunner and sorcerer all of which are easy-to-use damage dealers who specialize in ranged combat. The other options are berserkers and slayers (melee damage dealers), lancers (tanks), mystics (support healers), priests (primary healers), reapers (high mobility/dps) and finally warriors (tanks and/or melee damage dealers). Your race matters too. Different races come with different bonuses, different back stories, and different looks. The Popori are a particularly striking bunch; they're animals that have been made magical.

The underlying story here is somewhat bizarre—it starts with two gods dreaming up different races of creatures. But the bottom line is that your world is emerging from a contentious past—many of the races here faced serious challenges, including slavery. But now, all seven groups must work together to face a new enemy. The Argons have emerged from the underworld, and hope to take over TERA—which stands for The Exiled Realm of Arborea.

TERA also surpasses World of Warcraft in terms of graphics and sound—as it should, considering its higher system requirements. The visuals are a solid step up, with a bit more detail and clarity than WoW players will be used to. The sound effects and music are terrific, drawing the listener in to a fantasy world like few other games can.

If there's an area in which TERA falls short, it's that it can sometimes feel like more of a grind than WoW. I can't quite put my finger on the reason, but I think part of it is that TERA's quests are much heavier on basic errands—kill quests are a bit more entertaining than run over there and talk to this other guy" quests
date: especially when the combat system is a huge selling point. Of course
recommended: another part of it just might be that the game will feel familiar to any WoW player. But whatever the reason
hoursPlayed: I occasionally got the feeling that I was just running back and forth between markers on the map
voteText: rather than engaging in an epic quest with fascinating combat. These spells never lasted for too long
helpfulPercent: but they did detract from the experience.\n\nOf course
votesHelpful: TERA comes with a full suite of multiplayer features. You can team up with other players through a matching system
votesTotal: or by joining guilds for organized raids. Also there are PVP battleground areas and PvP realms
votesFunny: deathmatches that take place right in the normal game world
commentsCount: and duels.\n\nI almost hesitate to lavish so much praise on TERA. Given how much it has borrowed from World of Warcraft
column16: TERA is standing on the shoulders of a very tall
column17: very strong giant. But the bottom line is that TERA fixes the very worst aspect of WoW—the lame combat—while making some improvements to other features and doing a good job of emulating the basics. If you're looking for a good MMO
column18: TERA is an excellent choice."

reviewText: I think after 200 hours, I have an opinion on this game.  The combat is fun and punchy, similar to the likes of Monster Hunter (for readers who are familiar with that series), as the player must move about the battlefield avoiding attacks and striking when necessary.  It really does make for some pretty wild action at times.  There are several different classes, however the gunner" class is restricted to female high elves and castanics (dark elves
date: essentially) and the reaper class is only available to the "elin" race when another character on the player's profile is at level 40.  The classes all handle their roles quite well
recommended: and even the mystic and priest (support) classes are perfectly worthwhile to play as.  The mystic and priest aren't quite as fun to play as solo since they're limited for damage-dealing abilities
hoursPlayed: but they're a blast to play as in dungeons or when partied up with friends.\n\nThis game also has a crafting system
voteText: in which players can craft armor
helpfulPercent: weapons
votesHelpful: combat buff charms
votesTotal: and potions.  The game doesn't do a very sound job of explaining this system however unless you talk to a few scattered NPC's around Velika (the hub town) and even then
votesFunny: they give you a very basic tutorial of the system.  The crafting system IS worthwhile
commentsCount: as some of the best endgame equipment can only be made through this system.\n\nThe quests are pretty basic
column16: save for some level 61-65 quests at endgame that get a bit more interesting.  The story quests really aren't that bad
column17: and they even have some pretty nice looking cutscenes for more key points in the story.  Sadly they're not very complex quests and don't ask much of the player
column18: so if you go into this game expecting something along the likes of what an MMO such as "The Secret World" has to offer
column19: you may be disappointed.\n\nAside from that
column20: I find the "final" story quests of a particular region's questline to be particularly irritating.  The final quest is almost always a dungeon raid in which you need to gather up 4 other buddies and- of course- raid the dungeon.  These dungeons are incredibly difficult for a person to do alone on "normal mode
column21: but often can be completed with the collaboration of a DPS class and a support class.  The story quests spill over into these raid dungeons and must be completed to finish up that particular region's storyline.  Forcing people to either convince their friends to try out an MMO or team up with randoms is incredibly annoying.  Especially since there is a Solo mode" which tones down the dungeon so a single person can raid an albeit shorter version of the dungeon.  Why a person can't just complete the questline on "solo mode" is just annoying.  Aside from that
column22: that's the worst thing I really have to say about quests in this game.\n\nThis game is also free-to-play
column23: meaning it has a cash shop (obviously).  The only "pay to win" item in the store per-se is a scroll that will allow a person to reach level 60 instantly.  For a game like this
column24: this item really is made for people who are already familiar with the game
column25: as a newbie who uses this item will find themselves using a class that they have no idea how to use
column26: which is key for mastering this game's combat.  Most of the other items in the cash shop are also tradeable ingame
column27: including items like "name change vouchers" or keys for strongboxes.  Otherwise
column28: this game puts an emphasis on cosmetics and making your character look cool.  Ultimately
column29: the cash shop and the way it was implemented isn't something to lose sleep over and isn't an element that ruins the experience.\n\nFor those interested in how the cash shop works
column30: if you have "elite status" (a subscription service)

column32: but some of the items in the cash shop can go close to around $50-$60 without the elite status.  There are also elite status "vouchers" that can be traded ingame
column33: and 1-day vouchers can be earned at certain levels (I believe it's one per character).\n\nNow here's the tricky part- the community.  TERA has several different servers (3 PVE
column35: and moving a character between them costs a fair amount of money ($20 USD I believe).  So I'm not sure how the other servers fare for their communities
column36: but I tend to stick to the "Celestial Hills - Roleplaying" server

column42: so don't let it stop you from trying this game out!\n\nThe other issue with the community really isn't the community's fault.  Earlier in this review I stated how irritating it could be trying to get in a group of randoms to raid a dungeon - and the game has an interesting solution.  There's a "matchmaking" function that will set a player up in a party that's seeking to raid a region's dungeon.  Unfortunately
column43: most parties are often well-off for DPS classes and not near as many people take the time to play as a support class such as the mystic or priest.  I honestly don't blame people for not wanting to make a party of 5 DPS'ers

column45: this is a game worth playing.  It has fun combat

reviewText:
I have hundreds and hundreds of hours on the game but I have only just downloaded it on Steam. It used to be available on Steam, then they took it off, now it is back on! Most of my play was while the game was not available on Steam, so please ignore the fact that Steam only says I have a few hours on the game. I have a lot, lot more!

Coming from an FPS background, Tera suits me down to the ground. It is a fantasy mmo with FPS controls. The scale of the game is enormous and the graphics are simply glorious. This is an ideal game for FPS players who would like to branch out in to fantasy mmo.

The depth and detail in the game is just staggering. It is one enormous open-world that you can freely wander about in, and it's absolutely breathtaking.

The highlight of the game tends to be the spectacular artwork and the combat system. Gameplay is actually pretty simple and repetative although the end-game dungeons are much more inventive than the main game itself. By the time you get to the end-game, you are pretty much bored to death of the rinse-repeat nature of the quests.

There is a comprehensive gathering and crafting system, even if there isn't much of an introduction to it. I think it is fair to say that most players ignore it until later on, but it is worthwhile using the system as soon as you can. You can make what is a great deal of money for a low level player gathering, crafting and selling items to high level players.

There is also a very large achievement system with some very exclusive rewards. Of course there are exclusive items that need real money, but it's nice that you can obtain some genuinely desirable items through dedicated play. There are some really nice items that can won in a matter of hours and of course tons that can be obtained with in-game gold on the traders.

Unfortunately, there are some aspects of the game that you will either love or hate. The costumes and rides are simply amazing, albeit you must be prepared for outfits that are very much out-of-character and really do change the atmosphere of the game. Police, nurse, maid outfits and so on. You can even be a pink bunny and fight with a giant carrot if you want. Also the game is generally much more sexist than we are used to in the West. Particularly with the Elin character the game borders on the edge of unacceptable.

Of course mmo's are really about the community and the community with Tera is generally good, albeit there are a lot of school kids playing the game because it's free.

There are a few downsides though. The first is that it has a very limited end-game. Once you have completed the main game, then there are a half dozen or so dungeons and fifteen or so dailies and that's it. It quickly becomes incredibly repetitive. So try to enjoy the game as much as you can while levelling, because once you are there you might give up pretty soon after.

The second problem is for players in the EU. The EU version of the game is managed by Gameforge and they have completely wrecked the in-game economy. They have effectively made it Pay-To-Play, sapping every ounce of enjoyment out of the game unless you are a serious spend-a-holic. For that very reason the servers are much emptier than they were just a few short months ago, and everyone has been moving to Tera NA  ( North America ) where the game is managed so, so much better.

Recommended?  Well, and here comes the surprising part -  the Steam version IS the American run version. So, no matter where you are, you get the very best the game has to offer. People outside the US can expect a larger ping, but don't worry, it's fine for most countries. So..YES...try it. There are issues, but the wonderful graphics and exciting game-play are a must try.

reviewText:
[THIS REVIEW DOESN'T INCLUDE THE EUROPEAN SERVER, from Gameforge! Only the US server, from Enmasse]

A lot of people want to know: Is it Pay to Win?

I say: NO.
Of course, you can buy cosmetic items, mounts, even keys that unlocks certain box with dollar and sell it in AH, in-game, for gold, but I don't see it as a P2W feature, because it's not hard to make gold in-game.

The only advantage you really get using real money is buying the Elite Status, which you give like EXP Bonuses, and that sort of thing.

So don't be afraid, click PLAY and ENJOY!

I recommend PVE server for beginners, it is focused, as the name speak of itself, on PVE, and the PVP only happens if you invite someone to Duel.

reviewText:
Used to be an avid WoW player - But decided to give Tera a try.  I absolutely love how much we can customize our characters in the main screen.  The crafting and gathering aspect of the game are probably one of my favorite - It isn't something you need to farm for hours (At least at the lower levels, currently at 300 for most of my proffesions).  Beautiful scenery, great story line.  I also REALLY enjoy the fighting style, in WoW we select our target (And  can scroll through via the tab button) but here it's all point and shoot at the enemy which is a GREAT break from what I'm used too.

The only downfall is it does have a cash shop and I tend to get sucked into buying fashion items for my toons ;).  Elite status is amazing for this game - you can teleport to any city basically, which is really nice. BANK space in this game though is a huge issue, but they have items in the cash shop that you can buy to help with that.  I believe you can also spend in-game currency for items as well.

Over all I Love this game :)

reviewText:
Playing TERA solo vs. with friends:
TERA is extremely boring alone. If you want to play this game make sure you play it with friends. Not only will it make the game less difficult if you are playing a class that isn't good solo, but it will help kill the monotony of the questing/dungeons pre-end game. If you don't have friends, simply join a guild and quest with guildees. If you are tackling the game solo however here are some tips and warnings:
1. Make sure you are completeing quests in the right order, or else you will have to backtrack to the beginning of the zone to complete main quests you didn't realize you weren't completeing (it is easier to mess up than it sounds).
2. If you are playing solo make sure you pick a class that is good solo. A lot of classes in this game are balanced very strongly in a tank/dps/healing set-up and a lot of the big mobs in level 30+ zones get incredibly stronger than they were in previous zones. I recommend the brawler class as a great starting class. I played brawler and didn't have any issues with questing (or running dungeons) solo until around level 50+ when the level of the content was catching up with how far ahead my character was.

Zone Questing 1/10:
Every single zone in the game has the exact same leveling experience. 3 differen't locations per zone where you get quest type A. (kill 10 mobs quest), quest type B. (collect 10 items quest), and quest type C. (kill 5 big strong mob quest) once you complete those quests you move on to the next hub. After all 3 hubs in each sub-zone of a region you will get a quest chain to go through a solo-dungeon and repeat the whole thing and then eventually you will finally move on to the next leveled region and start all over again. I was hoping at least the expansion from 60-65 would have changed the questing experience a little, but honestly it was exactly the same. This game has by far the most undesireable questing experience I have ever participated in. I have played WoW, FFXIV, EverQuest, ArcheAge, Black Desert Online, Blade and Soul, Aion, Rift and many other MMOs, but this one takes the cake for the most boring grindy questing of them all. Luckily there are other options to choose from while questing.

End-game Questing N/A score:
This game really has none of it.

Dungeons 2/10:
Duneons in TERA are fun at first (literally the first dungeon), but you will soon realize like the questing that they are all exactly the same. A lot of them use the same assets so enemies and layout look exactly the same as the dungeon you just did, but with a differen't coat of paint. Essentially kill 3 rooms of mobs, fight a boss, next three rooms, another boss, ect. If you are using dungeons to get to 65 (that is what I would recommend) then prepare to take a lot of breaks, or put on some music while you do them. I didn't give dungeons a 1/10 simply because some of the bosses actually look pretty damn badass, and the gear you can get in dungeons is pretty awesome. However, dungeon bosses still all lack creative mechanics most you can just tank and spank, as well as any real exciting reason as to why you should want to kill them (until the expansion). Once you hit upper 50 dungeons and the expansion dungeons nothing really changes, but they get more exciting lore wise and you will actually feel like you have a purpose for running them to get geared for raids.

Raids (cannot give honest score):
Not a long section. I didn't play much of the raids, but they meet your typical mmorpg get geared in dungeons then increase in raid tier" format. From what I played of them they are pretty fun and challenging
date:
but I had a hard time keeping aggro so I didn't play much of them after getting the first raid tier gear.

Lore 3/10-->7/10 and Classes/Races/Combat 9/10:
I don't really have anything to say about the lore for pre-Arun expac
recommended: other than it is pretty boring and lacking (imo)
hoursPlayed: but Fate of Arun's story can get pretty exciting esspecially anything centered around the character Zolyn and her friends since they are the only redeeming lore characters in the whole game. As for classes warrior is a pain in the butt I don't recommend playing it if you are new to the game
voteText: but most of the classes that I tried seemed fun you purchase skills with money from trainers. Brawler was a blast for me to play and probably in my top 5 favorite classes of mmorpg history. The combat in TERA started the action style combat breaking away from games like WoW so in that regard the combat is fluid and great for the most part. Keeping aggro as a tank seemed to be difficult for me as the only thing
helpfulPercent: dps pull insanely high in this game
votesHelpful:
but that could be just because I suck at tanking (most likely). All in all this game is literally known for it's combat and is why it has so many players.

World PvP N/A score vs. Battlegrounds 8/10:
I didn't participate in end-game world pvp so I cannot say how fun it is although it seemed pretty fun like most game with world pvp. Prepare to get ganked A LOT when you are leveling though. And yes
votesTotal: this game has pvp AND pve servers so if you have a preference between the two you will be covered either way. Battlegrounds are fun and unique.... for what there is. I gave the battlegrounds a good score in this game
votesFunny:
but honestly there are a very low amount of them which can cause boredom to some players very quickly. If you want a more elaborate discussion on TERA's pvp feel free to message me. Also if you want to know about class balance I am the wrong person to ask as I only leveled to 65 with brawler and it was pretty OP at the time (they may have nerfed it by now).

Community 10/10 (biased I know):
First off this game has a very friendly community you will mostly only encounter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in pvp related activities (like when you get that one guy in battlegrounds who thinks he is better than everybody else and he is carrying the team). Secondly
commentsCount: my opinion is a little biased because this game has a huge anime crowd which I do not mind (warning to those of you who do not like anime you are going to be seeing fans of it pretty much around every corner). It only gets a little cringy around people who are huge Elin fanboys I recommend staying away from them anyway (no offense
column16:
but look at what you are playing a little more closely and realize why others might want to stay away from you).

Crafting N/A score:
It is your standard MMO crafting much like WoW's so I can't really throw an opinion on this one as it is a hit or miss for most. A lot of players don't care about the crafting at all.

Visuals/Graphics 9/10:
Game looks great and the artsyle is very pretty. Some zones have amazing screenshot-picture-perfect areas. Some of the best looking zones I have seen in an MMO (too bad the questing ruins it).

Q. Is the game P2W? ("Pay to win" meaning
column17: do you have to pay for in-game shop items with real money to not fall behind other players)\nA. No
column18: this game has the best F2P model I have ever seen. All of the in-game shop items are cosmetics to make your characters look cool. The game has a subscription you can pay
column19:
but honestly I found it pretty much worhtless. It doesn't give you anything you cannot get for free except a teleport book so you don't have to take flight paths.

Summary (tl:dr):
TERA has a lot going for it in the free to play market and can provide many hours of fullfilling mmo experience. The questing is beyond dull and more than half of the dungeons in the game have been cut out. Dungeons in general are uninteresting and bland until level 55+. Story isn't that great until Fate of Arun at 60

column21: but still fun nonetheless. Great game to try for free

reviewText:
So I bounce around between MMOs quite often. I've tried ESO, Aion, Rift, Runescape, WoW, Guild Wars, Blade and Soul, ect. But the one I keep coming back to is TERA. There's just something abut this game that the combat and story and world all comes together in somethng just right. So for those of you on the fence about this game here's how it goes:
-The story is about as interesting as you can get in an MMO storyline, exactly how you want it. Mindless enough that you can grind for hours and not forget really where you are storyline wise.
-The community is the friendliest I've ever seen (Keep in mind I really only play PvE) and we are all so helpful to each other. When questions are asked in world chat by new players they get legitemate help from everyone.
-Dungeon runs are fun! The combat makes them fast paced and intense, I've ran through with full groups fairly easily or put up a real challenge and had only 2 of us go through a 5 man dungeon.
-Weapons are class-bound, the weapon style you start with is what you get the whole game. Don't think of this as a negative though, when you're the priest in the party and that legendary staff drops then it's all yours.
-Now the real bread and butter: the combat. The True-action combat is what makes this game. Sure games like Blade and Soul and ESO could be a little faster but the combat in TERA stays true to what it promises. If you miss your dodge or block, you will be punished for it. If you dodge roll into a powerful counter attack, it will do serious damage. Skill combo(ing) is up to you as a player and you'll discover certain skills flow better with others as far as animation timing goes. The combat is also freaking fun. You aren't simply trading blows with goblins for a few min then moving on, you're engaged and avoiding attacks and timing your own.

To sum it up: This game is free and I've sunk in almost 600 hours into it. There's a reason for that. The game is fun, fast-paced, and has a lot of replay value with so many classes. It's continued to keep my personal interest as developers are constantly working to update the game for us. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
i'm seriously blown away. i should have been playing this game for a long time now, it's everything i've always wanted. i don't know when it went free to play, but once i saw it did on their website i was going to dl it and start playing. then i saw it was coming to steam on the 5th, so i waited to get it on steam.
what a game so far, fluid mechanics, using an xbox 360 controller works really well, fantastic graphics, and beautiful environments.
i marathon'd this and got my first char up to 20 in my first sitting and saw a few of the different areas. simply amazing.

only a few GRIPES though and it's just because i'm picky and notice it.
-no vysnc option and obvious tearing at certain times. (even with hardware vysnc on or on adaptive)
-mini-map is kinda laggy and takes some getting used to
-when on a mount sometimes changing direction while moving the camera causes a slight blip in which way the character is facing, just not 100% super fluid animations on everything.
-it's not pay to win but i want them to take my money.
-the game crashes and resets my evga precision x settings, sometimes just a blip and i can keep playing, sometimes it freezes all the way and i need to force close it, restart the client, and steam. happens maybe every 4-5 hours of gameplay. makes me take a break lelelel
-sometimes i autoloot, sometimes i don't, sometimes my companion auto attacks, sometimes he doesn't.


nothing game killing and on the PLUS side, there are great features that are really drawing me in.
-mat farming can be done with multiple people at a time, speeds it up, AND gives you more than doing it alone
-mat farming gives you awesome buffs
-enchanting doesn't destroy your items! only the mats used to enchant! THANK GOD!!!!
- you have to be about 10 levels over the recommended level of the area to start getting less gold and exp.
-i'm playing as a mystic, and i feel really really self sufficient. i'm a support class that's very balanced and do not feel tied down by pots.
-the diversity of enemies is immense. it's really refreshing.
-the trade market is really well done.

and it's because of those pluses that i will be playing for a long time, and after these boosts wear off from this initial release, will definitely support the developer.

11/10 would play a non-gameforge game again. sorry that eu users have to put up with them. enmasse seems pretty legit.

updated 5/7/15 after 25 hours logged (added the type of controller i use, and did a slight reformat stating my complaints first and the pluses second)

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game?  Do I recommend the soul-sucking monster of an MMO that has, effectively, ruined my life?  Yes, I do.  I started playing Tera over a year ago- January of last year, actually; I just checked- and while I've had brief breaks during that time, I've still been playing through the majority of the time that I've had the game downloaded.

For the first several months, I was absolutely a casual player, slowly leveling up my main.  (Who was, at the time, a warrior-class Castanic; now I main an Elin reaper, though as of the gunner's release, I'm liking it an awful lot.  Oh lord.  But I digress.)  I really didn't know much about my class at all, and looking back, there're some things that I really wish I'd known.

Eventually, however, after shuffling servers for a bit (before returning to my main server- VoT), I hit level 60, which was the level cap at the time.  It was pretty damnably satisfying, I have to admit.  Then I decided to work on my reaper, and I think that's about when I changed from very casual, to playing the game a hell of a lot more than I had been before, almost exclusively on my reaper.

The gameplay is addictive- while the initial grind to the level can get tedious, it's most definitely doable within a few weeks, if you're playing fairly casually, and within a few days if you're really working on it.  For example, I made my gunner earlier today, and so far I've gotten her to level 31; the class came out around 24 hours ago, as of writing this review, and I know that people have already gotten their gunners to 65.  Of course, they were racing in order to get an achievement, but still, the point stands- it's possible to go a long way, solo, in a fairly short span of time.

But once you hit the level cap, that's really where most of the harder PvE content begins, and honestly, where you really start to learn your class.  Not that you learn nothing before then, but you definitely learn quicker what you should and shouldn't do when you're getting oneshotted repeatedly, due to using a dodge skill before it was really necessary.

This is something I've learned the hard way, unfortunately.

Admittedly, there is a definite tendency for the same enemies to be re-colored, and used over again, without really changing the mechanics of the fight at all.  But at the same time, it's important to note that there's no tab-targeting in this game, and- as far as I'm aware- there aren't a whole lot of lock-on skills either.

For a comparison of how the controls work (at least for moving your character- the skills are another story entirely), think Skyrim.  You have the WASD pad, and a free-moving third person camera, and a menu that pulls up when you hit ESC.  (Or rather, it was where you hit ESC and it pulled up.  Now you have to go into the UI Options in order to set it to do so, which I'd honestly recommend, because otherwise the screen looks cluttered, and it's not like you can click on it without hitting ESC anyway, since the mouse controls the camera.)

Then the skills are on a fairly standard scheme, where you have one row of skills as the number keys just above the keyboard, and another row as the F keys above that.  This can also be changed, and easily.  Just find keybinds that work for you, and work out which skill you want to put on which key as you go, since you get more skills as you level.

Anyway, I'm rambling.



Graphics:
4/5 - They're gorgeous, but I have to deck a star due to the fact that, generally speaking, you have to turn the video settings down in order to not have a whole lot of graphical lag.  And even then, you might still get an only half-decent framerate.

Character creation/customization:
4/5 - Again, there're some seriously gorgeous characters that you can make with this game.  But then, you can also make some of the most horrifying, hideous, eye-searing, Lovecraft-worthy abominations you can imagine.  Just try hitting the randomize button.  Trust me.  Then, some of the facial types/adornments tend to look better than others, though fiddling with the sliders tends to work wonders on almost any of them.  (Almost.  There are some that not even I can save.)

And the costumes.

Oh my god, the costumes.  Since the initial publishers tend to make most of their revenue off of costumes for Elins, along with female Castanics/Elves, the costumes tend to be more focused around them.  And generally, I have no complaints, since those are also what I tend to play as.  One of the most recent batches of costumes is absolutely glorious, except for a pretty glaring bug on some of the dresses.  Ahem.  They really should've caught that.  But anyway, if you're going to be playing as a race other than a female Elin/Castanic/Elf, and costumes are something vital to your experience, just note that your choices are going to be more limited.

(On the bright side, however, you can also get dyeable costume versions of basically all any and all of the armor in the game- with things called fashion coupons- for any race/gender/class out there.)

Gameplay:
5/5 - Like I mentioned, the initial leveling process can be a bit tedious, but I'm still giving gameplay- in general- five stars, due to the fact that the combat in general is the best I've come across, in any MMO.  PvP is extremely fun, as are the hard-mode dungeons, and that's not even mentioning open-world PvP on three of the servers, and the battlegrounds, which are, in essence, two teams of players pitted against each other.  In Corsairs' Stronghold, for example, you have two raids of twenty people each, trying to beat each other.

(The goal is either to defend a crystal/break the crystal, with one team on offense and the other on defense, for the first round, and then the roles are reversed- the team that was defending the crystal has to do slightly more damage than the other team managed in the last round, within the same amount of time, or less, and the other team has to attempt to keep them from getting that much damage, until the time of the match runs out.  It's ridiculously fun, but I'd definitely recommend looking up guides on Corsairs' Stronghold before you actually try it, so that you're not running around like a headless chicken, with no idea what you're doing, or where you're going.  Corsairs' Stronghold is unlocked at level 30, by the way, with the rest of the battlegrounds unlocking at 65, I think?)

So, yeah.  The PvP is phenomenal.  Just note that if you decide to play on a PvP server, it's best if you switch off of the main channel while you're leveling, and until you have at least decent gear.  (Oh, and if you're planning on doing PvP, save the boxes you get.  The next cycle of highest-tier gear will require materials that come from the boxes, so it would be a good idea to save them from the start, if you can stand it.)

Atmosphere:
4/5 - While some of the costumes can be immersion-breaking, if that's something you're concerned about, I honestly think that the atmosphere of most of the areas in the game more than make up for it.  If you get a chance, check out the location called Scythera Fae.  Just be careful not to go too far outside of the town, seeing as it's a high-level area.

Community:
?/5 - It really depends, honestly.  There're nice people, fantastic people, really ridiculously rude people, and straight-up asshats- along with everyone in between- just like anywhere else.  Really, though, I haven't had a bad experience with the other players at all, which is pretty nice.  (It helps that En Masse has excellent support, and that the block system is easily implemented if there's someone that's really grating on your nerves.)

Overall:
5/5 - After the time I've spent playing this game, I think it would be dishonest to give it anything less.  Even if it has its flaws, it's fun and graphically gorgeous, with the best combat and PvP that I've seen to date.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Far from being Pay2Win
+ Scenery porn
+ Addictive combat system
+ Nice and helpful community (!)
+ Backtracking isn't that much of a pain in the butt here.
+ Same goes to grinding; it's not that bad here.
+ Really, REALLY good graphics.
+ Each class is very different and well balanced...

Cons:
- ...except Gunner. It's insanely op...
- ...and available only for castanic and high elves females.
- 2 classes (gunner and reaper) are only for specific races and genders.
- Generic quests.
- Some bosses spawn only in one specific place and there might be a huge amount of people who want to kill them or steal a first hit.

To be perfectly honest, TERA might be the best free MMORPG I've ever played. Every location looks great, combat is really engaging and exploring is so much fun. Sometimes we might get a little bit tired of seeing some location for a long time, for me it was Valley of Titans and Oblivion Forest, but other than that I really can't say anything really bad about this game! I tend to lose interest in MMOs rather quickly, but this one? I'm going to stay for a long time. If you can't decide if you should play it or not, go and play it, without a doubt or hesitation, DO IT!
9.5/10

reviewText:
Although I just started playing this game, it feels a lot more refined than other MMOs in terms of combat mechanics. Starting character customization is somewhat lacking with limited hair color and eye color options but there is a modest selection of hairstyles and facial complexions. The real customization comes in costumes and armour selection. There's multiple slots for costumes allowing for mixing and matching of different costume sets. No two players are the same as everyone tends to find their own personal way of mixing costumes.

Most MMOs I've played tend to pan handle you in terms of where you can go. In Tera, my personal favourite is climbing the mountains that are littered across the landscape. Took me a while to realise but I was enlightened to discover I could go on top of mountains in an area that otherwise looked inaccessible. However, with freedom of discovery comes glitches. Avoid waterfalls as my character got stuck inside one behind all the rocks.

Level balancing seems a little funky, NPCs two levels above are god-like and difficult to take down. NPCs two levels below are weaksauce to the point of boredom. However, levels matching you are well balanced so there's that. But I'm finishing story quests so fast that I reach NPCs several levels above me... I welcome the challenge, however. I don't PVP much, I'm more of a PVE-hero player. But I do have limited experience with PVP in this game and I have to say that it's fun and I'll go that far. The guilds are oddly setup, it requires player discretion but that's something you can easily get used to. People are vastly organised in guild/alliance battles and I appreciate that.

Farming is immensely easy. My only gripe is NPCs respawn too quickly. I can cartwheel a small group of NPCs indefinitely or repeatedly take down a mini-boss. World bosses are exceptionally rare and that's something I appreciate more.

Server populations are still very high, 2 servers are dead but that's expected of a game many years old. I'm on Ascension Valley and valkyries are (as of this review) still flying to-and-from Velika like popcorn out of a pot.

And to all those people that say Priests can't solo anything: I've solo'd dungeons, mini-bosses, groups of mini-bosses, and BAMs with a Priest. Git gud or go home kiddies.

Finally, I'm a big fan of the anime-style special effects. 7/10

reviewText: As a veteran MMO player (wow, eve, guildwars2, swtor, etc.) Tera is one of my favourites. the game has many of the same things you find in most mmos and free to play mmos such as a subcription model that provides benefits to those willing to pay monthly, thankfully this does not take away from the free to play side unlike most mmos that offer subscription options, Dungeons and Raids, PVP to a crazy extent, etc.. The micro transactions are not game breaking from my experience and most things can be purchased with in game gold from the player market.\nMy favourite aspect of Tera and the main reason to choose it over other free to play option on the market is the combat, they dont lie when they promise true action combat, using your skills plus generic attack feels fluid, dodging/blocking in combat are both key. all in all best mmo combat I have experienced.\nLast word, dont wanna make this a long read but if you are looking for a fun, hack and slash mmo with fun monsters and decent depth Tera is for you.

reviewText:
TERA is a good bit of fun, but in spite of how long it has been out, there are one or two apsects of it that could use some work, in my opinion.  Here is a short breakdown of what do and dont like about the game.

Pros:
-Good character customization
-Fairly graphically impressive
-Unique/distinctive races and classes
-The game rewards players for playing their class correctly
-TERA sports a pretty well executed player-driven economy, which is helpful both making profits AND speeding along gear advancement

Cons
-Some really cool classes are gender-locked, and even gender/race-locked.
-Cosmetic items and faster mounts are hard to come by, although I can't really fault the devs for wanting to pay the bills.

reviewText:
Me and a friend once walked into a large guild meet up house and admired the architecture for a couple of minutes. There was a large group of people in the middle of the enormous room, but me and my friend didn't pay much attention to them. When we started getting closer to the group, I noticed something rather off... Once I realized what was going on, I nervously pointed it out to my friend.

At least 15 to 20 Elins stood in the very middle of the enormous room.
I was a Human and my friend was a Baraka, so we stood out like a sore thumb.
We were just standing around, off to the side.
The Elins began turning towards us, one by one.
They stared at us, like we were never supposed to be there.

Both me and my friend ran for our very lives.

10/10 Best horror game.

reviewText:
Just to get some things clear. I started this game wanting to rip someone's throat out because I kept getting Errors (which actually happen because of AVG). I didn't know this at the time and about rage quit. Boy am I glad I stayed steady and found a fix. I have to say, I've never been a big MMORPG fan but this changes everything. It's like my favorite parts of other games combined into an MMO experience.

Some analysis on certain aspects of the game:
- Combat and classes are essentially Monster Hunter 3
-World is absolutely amazing, combine some of the best fantasy environments you've seen and it's this game. From floating magical islands to thorny dark twisted caverns. This game's got it all.
- RPG is something lacking. I find myself walking up to the quest icon, spamming F and walking away. Maybe I should look into the lore....
- Boob physics
- Healthy range of races from hulking rock-people to what I assume to be lolis
- Interesting alchemy, enchanting, and crafting mechanics. Nothing new, but interesting.

Do recommend if you're looking to scratch that fantasy itch.

Edit: After reaching level 40 and 36 in-game hours the only thing I will edit about this is about the combat. Early game combat is, indeed, a simplified MH3 system. However, after about, say, level 25, things get much more complex. You gain abilities as you level up which you can chain together to crush enemies with unprejudice violence. Co-op also becomes a vital role to acquiring rare items and beating raid crucibles. It's very fun, but you better pray to the Maker that you have a healer with half a cup of sense.

Another thing I might mention is that the developers are still very active in the community. It's nice to see updates every holiday and essentially twice a month. That's more than I can say for other games *looks at The Forest*

reviewText: As someone who has played thousands of hours of multiple MMORPGs over the years, I can easily say that TERA has by far the best combat system out of all of them, it has true action combat, that means aimed attacks, dodging, timing, invulnerability frames, etc... It adds another layer of skill and depth onto the mechanics that already exist in most modern MMORPGs. Other than the combat however, TERA doesn't do all that much to make itself standout from other MMORPGs, but it really doesn't need to, because for what it is and what it tries to accomplish, it does things very well.\n\nAnother point I'd like to bring up is the business model of this game. It originally required a $15 a month subscription-fee, however as you can probably imagine, that was quickly abandoned for a free-to-play model. Many free-to-play games in this day and age, particularly MMOs, are often either straight up pay-to-win, or they will artificially slow you down so much that you need to pay to have a good experience. TERA thankfully does not fall under these categories. Rather, TERA only really allows you to pay for fair things like costumes, accessories, weapon skins, mounts, and some consumables and convenience features like XP boosters and travel journals. It also has an optional Elite" subscription service that gives you some nice perks such as a unique mount
hoursPlayed: among other things which can be found listed on their website. So I will conclude this point by saying that I don't think I have played a free-to-play MMO with a more fair business model than TERA.\n\nOverall TERA is an excellent MMO and has been sucking away my time ever since it found it's way onto Steam

Hello.

My life has been Filled with TERA; social skills = failing...

What is sun?

------------------Actual Review-----------------

First off, I highly do not recommend this game to people who have the following traits;

-Does not like to spend money
-Likes to have social interation outside of Tera
-Likes to enjoy the outside world
-Dislikes massive boobs and heavily sexualized armor for both male and female models
-Dislikes humorous communities of people who don't give a damn about anything except getting the next drop
-Enjoys boring, long combat scenarios of button mashing and no interation with the environment
-Dislikes memorizing long, lengthy mechanics for bosses that if you don't, you die
-Dislikes massive guild alliances where you actually work together for a common cause
-Boobs
-Dislikes a large, deep, and thrilling lore surrounding The Exiled Realm of Arborea
-Dislikes some grindy dungeons that force you to be on your A-Game to get end-game gear
-Dislikes a Game where you actually have to have skill
-Dislikes a Game that is not Gear based
-Dislikes having a wallet filled with cash, isntead of EnMasse Reciepts
-Dislikes long, length dungeons
-Dislikes fun communities that help people out (except for Global chat - never ask global chat)
-Dislikes growing, enterable (That's a word right?) economies that don't frown on new players
-Active and responsive admins and GMs
-Dislikes Amazing scenery
-Dislikes epic battles
-Dislikes fluid combat where you have to move

OKAY. So, you like all the stuff I said above? You want to immerse yourself in a great world filled with a diverse group of people of all ethnicities, socio economic classes, idiologies, and beliefs?

Don't download this game.

You won't ever again.

You won't do ANYthing besides TERA ever again.

Only 136 hours you may say?

Downloaded this game a week ago.

However... if you are foolish enough to hit download"... I only have one thing to say to you...

Welcome. You're never leaving

reviewText:
Before you read further into why I can't play this game, I want to discuss its good points:

-Visually ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gorgeous.  TERA's art is phenomenal.
-Incredibly fluid and rewarding combat system.  It's like an actual fighting game, and ranged characters can really take advantage of the real-time aiming.  Archers are a blast.
-Fantastic character customization.  The creation system leads to beautiful characters every time, suited to their roles and races.
-Blocking that isn't hindered by a pre-set value.  If you're a Berserker or a Lancer you can block for days and you'll just soak the damage.
-Lancers are by far the coolest tanking class I've ever seen.  I want more games to operate their tanks like TERA does Lancers.

Now here's why I can't play TERA:

-It's too, too Korean for my tastes.  It's so anime Toonami would probably stream it after dark.  It's sylized in such a way that everything is sexualized -- and I won't fault them on this because the men are just as sexualized as the women.  However that's not why I play my games.  When I roll up a tanky female character I want a modicum of protection, not a plate bikini and boobs that move when standing still.

-The grind happens almost immediately after you exit the basic" zone and go to Lumbertown.  The game is ingenious in this way; it throws the first 12-14 levels at you like it's no big deal

reviewText:
I've been a player of TERA since the early summer of 2014, prior to the release of the Wounded World patch, which introduced the T15 gear and a batch of 4 new dungeons. Since then the world of TERA has only grown larger, with the release of a new continent, the increased cap level from 60 to 65, more dungeons, more battlegrounds and skycastles (guild halls), and the recent release of a new class. And let's not forget the numerous bi-monthly events or season festivals that happen all year long, in-between major patches!

TERA is with certainty one of the liveliest free MMOs out there, with a developer team constantly working on bringing something new to the table.

Major draws:
+ dynamic combat, with a wide array of skills, complete with glyphs to improve upon them, and the ability to chain attacks
+ vast, beautiful and detailed world. From fairy forests, to deserted ruins to alien corrupted lands, TERA has it all, and a decent lore to tie it all together
+ several races to choose from, players can choose to be a human hero or a fearsome amani, a luscious castanic or perhaps an asian loli elin
+ 10 classes to choose from, though as a -, 2 of the classes are race and gender-locked
+ dungeons and raids are awesome fun

Major flaws:
- holy trinity. Though they recently improved upon it by allowing dungeon queues without tanks, it suffers from a great imbalance of classes, having only 2 healer classes, 1 tank, 5 pure dps classes and a hybrid tank/dps class
- dungeon queue times, which is tied to the aforementioned issue. a dps can take even over 2h in queue before finding a group (happened today even) while queues for a tank/healer take less than 5 min
- rather big gear treadmill, only made worse by a community heavily focused on ilevel (gearcheck rating), which usually leaves most racing for the top gear the second a new one is released or getting left behind with slim to none chances of finding parties to gear up at a later time
- enchanting system that is a huge gold sink, with a big chance to fail at higher levels. Luckily it doesn't revert any progress made up to that point.
- boring, repetitive sidequests. It's either kill 10 of this mob, 8 of that, fetch 5 flowers type of quests only
- rather rudimentary character customization, no mix&match, just full costumes, but it does offer a pretty big selection of free in-game skins via the Fashion Coupons shop

The game also has an optional subscription, which is in no way mandatory to fully enjoy the game. It does offer some time-saving solutions, like an xp boost that with help level characters twice as fast or being able to list twice as many items on the trading post and a world atlas that allows you to teleport to cities and towns instead of embarking on a pegasus flight, but it doesn't hold too much value otherwise. It's an ideal not pay-to-win model, complete with a system that allows in-game trades of store-purchased goods for gold between players.

reviewText:
Overall, I must give this game a thumbs down. The combat is fun, especially when fighting the larger boss types. Plus, the game is rather pretty. However, the questing follows the exact same formula throughout each and every zone that a player visits on their way to 65, and they aren't very memorable or meaningful.

The only quests available are summed up in six words: Go there. Collect or Kill that.

That's pretty much it. There just isn't enough variety to make the storyline deep and engaging, and make the player feel they are impacting anything besides their wallet and experience bar. There were plenty of opportunities to place some interactive environmental mechanics that didn't involve simply waiting on a timer to expire and killing the magically appearing monsters. However, they were wasted.

Tera's shallow depths do not take long to explore, and that's a shame.

reviewText:
On the downslope.

I started playing Tera about a month after launch and have around 3k hours into it and every class max level/ geared (as of wounded world anyway)
I main sorcerer, priest, and warrior mainly.

It was my first MMo that I really dug into, I had tried some others but just never got hooked and I realized with Tera it was the tab combat that was ruining things for me.
Finally an mmo where you could actually kite properly, where hitboxes were actually realistic, and placement was just as important as skill cycling. And the thrill of iframing attacks. Tera is (though should more say was") a very skill based game so it was very gratifying to see yourself not just get new gear and clear content but become a very skilled player which allowed you to do even more.

Once you really learned your class and the game well you were in a new "club" at that point
recommended: running things without a healer or tank. The player skill ceiling really opened up new ways to have fun and play the game.\n\nBack to my history a bit; since this was my first mmo I really took my time with it and soaked up the experience. Given back then the game was much harder and it took longer to level. It was a game that was best played with other people (which seems to be a foreign concept in mmo's these days) Good gear only came from the dungeons
hoursPlayed: back then you would only be able to +6 it unless you had a capped main that could feed your alts. The big world monsters that many quests needed were a good 4 times harder than they are now. And needed a party to take down unless you were a badass.\n\nAnd years ago before ftp the community was really great

reviewText:
Of all the f2p mmos out there this one is quite enjoyable and I have played it plenty prior to its steam release.

Pros:
-Thanks to a modified unreal 3 engine the game does looks quite amazing and is fairly well optimized
-A good variety of races and classes at your disposal that all play very unlike each other
-You directly control your character which does allow for quite skillful play
-Expect many new players to group up with due to the recent steam release
-The community is overall rather friendly from what I have experienced and quite helpful if you have any questions
-A huge world with a immense variety of environments to discover and beautifully crafted dungeons
-Does have pve, pvp and even roleplay servers for those looking for rp
-A good amount of character customization

Cons:
-There are a lot of fetch quests which not everyone might like, though due to the combat system its not that bad as in other mmorpgs
-The game has a lot of interesting mechanics such as the stamina system with bonfires and buff charms but the sheer amount of content might be a little overwhelming at first. It needs a little time to get the hang of.
-The artstyle is not for everyone and you might find yourself disliking it or the Elin race. Though If you don't like it simply don't play as one.
-37 gb download! Might take a while...


If you're looking for something new to sink some time in give it a go. Its free so whats to lose?
Grab some friends , level up together, explore a new world and first and foremost, have fun.

reviewText:
First and foremost, I played a bit before launch on steam, only ever got in my 30s level range. I mainly decided to play because it was launching on steam, and I had heard good things about the combat.

Combat -

Quick and intuitive, I love this game's combat. Like the trailer says, nearly everything is skillshot based. Even healing, which I'm learning a bit of. Dodging is satisfying, and the combat equally so. I do have a bit of a gripe though. And it's kind of related to combat. But that's for the next section.

Balance -

With the new addition of the Gunner class it seems to outshine most of its competitors  in ranged dps. I don't know, as I've not played either archer or sorceror, but its mobility seems a great boon to the class in comparison to the others. I'm not sure how Reaper plays, as I've yet to play one either, so I can't talk about that. Either than that, the community seems biased towards certain classes, and against others. But if you play what you feel like, you'll have fun. And that's what it's about, playing what you think is fun, and possibly proving that bias wrong.

Grind - I'm only level 30 or so at the time of this review, but I can say that I can see the grind already, but that's expected with a korean MMO, and frankly, the combat system makes this so much better. Since the combat seems to fresh, it's easier to take down monsters and not think about it. I got an achievement for killing 5000 monsters the other day, and was actually surprised that I'd already killed that many. World bosses are fun, as they're a break in the grind where you get to dodge, duck, dip, dive, and dodge around the battlefield as this thing clearly tries to eat your face. And every few levels or so you get shards to a new weapon for your level bracket that feels so much better when you finally find that last piece. All in all, this is one of the first korean MMOs where I do not mind the grind.

Visuals:
Actually quite impressive. That's one thing I've learned from playing f2ps, you can find some real gems out there. Tera is one of them, while yes it's one that is definitely revelling in the sexualization that most korean mmos play on, it could be worse. It could be Scarlet Blade. But this isn't a review on that game so I won't get into detail. Now granted, it was a p2p that was converted to f2p.

Now, something in between visuals and combat, I wanted to add. Monsters have signs, quite like monster hunter or other games, that show when it's going to unleash a big attack. This I like, as it's mostly fluid in every animation I've seen for a monster, and sometimes you have to look close to realize it's the telltale sign that you're about to have your butt handed to you.

F2P-

Actually well done, most everything is cosmetic or rng based (lockboxes) purchases, experience bonuses and the like are able to be purchased, but that's not really p2w and as others have said before, double experience events are plentiful.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now I realize I've been going on and on about things that I like, granted I don't like everything. So, let's list some things I don't like.

Negatives:

-Gender-locked/Race-locked classes: Yeah, yeah, gripe at me, I'm sorry I understand why these classes are locked to specific genders and races, but I would still like to have an Amani gunner, or even a Popori reaper. You can only animate so much on a free to play budget, I understand, which is why this is really only a small complaint, however it does irritate me a little bit.

-Balance: I've stated my biggest complaint here, but it's seeming more apparent as I level gunner, that why should I bother with either archer or sorceror? I love magic classes, but the idea of standing still and casting really makes me not want to roll one. And it's really just that, the mobility aspect.

-Community: Stay away from Global chat and you'll be golden. Most everyone I've met so far have been awesome. But Global, Global is nearly the equivalent to Barrens chat from WoW.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

All in all, I'd likely give this game an 7/10, it's phenomenal, but I've also not seen nearly half the game yet. So for now, let's stick with mostly positive.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I don't post reviews often, but Tera was one of those few games to leave an impact, so be gentle. My formatting or wording may not be the greatest, or my points. But no sense in trolling.

reviewText:
*A quick note that needs to be said is, I played Tera in 2014 but then took a six month break and now I have returned. With that said, I am basing my review on what I know of when I played in the past. Most of my review will be correct but some points that I make might be out of date.*

Tera is a MMORPG game and is very popular and seems to be growing, definitely with the recent update. I think that everyone should try Tera out if you have any interest in MMO's. It's a FTP (Free To Play) and is not a P2W (Pay to win) game in any means.

It's well balanced and has a lot of content to keep you busy. You start off with just learning the basics and doing quests such as: talk to this guy, kill 10 monsters in this area, and so on. At the start it's very basic but when you level up you get a lot more in depth quests that make the game enjoyable for hours and hours at a time. Once you level up you start to get dungeon quests. When going into a dungeon you can do them solo but it's very hard so most people team up with a party of 5. You fight your way through the dungeon and you reach a boss and sometimes the dungeon will have more than one boss. These bosses are HUGE and super powerful and you need your entire team to be on their A game to defeat the boss. The dungeons are always a blast and you get some nice loot too :).

Another thing that you can do in Tera is forming Guilds. In a Guild you are able to of course be social with other players but you can do missions with them. You are given the option when you're in a Guild to do Guild missions which require people only from your Guild. I like this concept because it gives a reason for players to join a Guild and be social with other players. Another thing which I am not sure how popular it is but the idea is great. You are able to do GvG (Guild verse Guild) where you do exactly that. You PvP (Player verse Player) against other Guilds and your Guild has stats and ranks.

The combat system is something that I love about Tera. When you're in combat, you don't simply click on the enemy and watch your guy beat the monster up. That's not how Tera works at all. You actually have to aim all of your skills including your basic attack. I like this a lot because I feel like it makes the game a little harder which makes the skill cap higher. This also makes you have to work harder to become a strong player because if you can't land your skills when you're fighting a boss your team will know if you're slacking.

Just like any other MMO there is a lot to learn. So if you're playing Tera and you find yourself lost just look up some guides on your class. Also play with friends! The only reason why I took a break from the game was because I didn't have anyone to play with. So be social in the game and invite your friends!

Have fun and good luck in Tera!

reviewText:
So, I bought this game on May 30th, 2012, originally on EA's Origin platform. I had the CE, an early start and a founder package. You know, the works. I enjoyed what I saw at the time but due to my easily influenced brain, my friends at the time pulled me right back to World of Crack. It wasn't until just now, today, November, 8th, 2015 that I remembered I had all of that. And so, our journey begins.

Upon logging in, my original character is still there waiting for me in some valley but I figure after so much time and likely tons and tons of changes, I may as well make a new character. So I whip up an Archer. This review is widely based on Archer gameplay (for 12 hours), but will include some other comments.

Pros:

-Action oriented gamplay: There are very few MMOs that get this right. TERA is one of them. The movement is fluid, just like you'd expect from a decent MMO and the combinations of things are just super duper fun. As an archer I find myself bouncing around quite frequently, a far-cry from standing in one place and mashing one button.

-BEAUTIFUL graphics. I can't even begin to describe how nice this game looks. Just loading up the character creator and the details on the character faces is mind blowing. Then you log in and everything is just super pretty. It is a pleasure to wander around in.

-TERA is -actually- free to play. It's not pay to win, you can't just toss money at your character and kill everything with a button. Most of what's available on the cash shop is also available to players for gold, and nothing in the cash shop is an easy-win button. (which is great, because I'm on PVP server)

-PVP! World PVP! I'm experiencing right now in TERA what I remember experiencing in my first moments of World of Warcraft and my leveling experience on a PVP server: paranoia. This may not be for everyone, but being on the edge of my seat while I'm leveling up and grabbing new gear is one of the best ways to not fall asleep.

-Tons and tons and tons and tons of cosmetic options and superb character customization. Of course, you can make a funny looking character, but most of the time you can come out with something to your liking.

-The variety of sounds that nofify you of accomplished goals are nice, they're not annoying. There's even a fairy side-kick thing that tells you when you have mail.

-Achievements, for the obsessive.

-Absolutely no shortage of quests to do

-Very little restriction on crafting, because who doesn't love crafting?

-Pets you can collect

-Dungeons (haven't seen them yet, but I'm assuming they're at least a little fun with a good group)

Cons:

-Elin. I have to mention this because it's the glaring, obvious thing to mention. I have an Elin myself, she's a cute little sorcerer that blows things to pieces and kills everything with fire, but judging by a lot of steam reviews and other people in TERA who happen to be playing Elin, some of them (I really don't want to say most) seem to be the waifu pedophile crowd. So it is definitely a con for me to be forming a group and wondering which one of my party members is a sexual predator.

-The community (the vocal part that you see speaking in chat channels). This is almost always a con in just about any online game that allows people to speak to each other publicly. It is your typical out-of-touch with reality manchild fare who think Donald Trump is a legitimate choice for the 2016 presidential elect and have such a weak grasp on social issues you wonder how they go outside and make friends.

-Quest variety. Although there are many, many quests to do, there needs to be more variety, and this is kind of a small con because it doesn't really bother me all that much. I come from a long line of MMOs in my history, starting with Anarchy Online. A game in which you spent nearly all of your time just sitting around in the wilds killing mobs for loot and experience and no written goal telling you where to go. Not a huge con for me, but likely a bigger con for others.

-Armor variety. So far, from level 1 to 21 on my Archer, almost all of the armor is the same exact texture with a different color filter placed over it. I hope it starts to look cooler at some point.

Overall, this is a great free to play MMO. I have spent a lot of time looking for one that can actually hold my attention and TERA is it. If you can look past these cons then definitely give it a go.
