reviewText:
A once good game, soiled by the lazyness of both the developer, bluehole studio, and the north american publusher, En Masse Entertainment. I've played this game since the first beta test, but haven't played it much on steam due to the many problems i've come across in this game.

+ Very good combat system
+ Impressive animations in skills
+ Somewhat good graphics, aibet a few low res textures.
+ Lots of players

- Very very very badly optimized.
- Super annoying and immature player base
- Corrput publisher
- Endgame is very grindy + pay to win.

It might seem like the game is not Pay to win, but by the time you're at endgame, you NEED to get your weapon to +15 in order to even be relevant in endgame content, as well as PVP. It's a shame the game has gone down this horrible path, but the developers have already moved on to making a sequel, and the publisher stopped caring a while ago. Just wait for blade and soul.

reviewText:
I've got more than 60 hours in this game, and I really enjoy it, but I'm sad to say I won't be playing it again.

First the pros:
The art is beautiful in this game, especially for an MMO. Honestly, that's what first grabbed my attention for the game. I also like that the game is just as easy to play solo as it is with others. I enjoyed the combat system, think the UI is pretty efficient, and liked the crafting system. The characters and quests have a bit more thought put into them than your typical MMO, and that's pretty cool to. It's also fairly easy to get started in the game, and you can jump into it quickly, or take your time and look around. I also liked that, while you can certainly pay to get some pretty cool extras, I never felt like it was a pay-to-win game (that said, I have not played the PvP aspect of the game).

Then the cons:
There were only a few things I didn't like in this game. The partying system is not friendly to players who are new to MMOs. I had a friend play with me, and, when I wasn't there, they had to google how to get some things done just to basic stuff in chat. You also can't tell what channel someone is on, even if they're in your party, although this can be worked around with a bit of communication. The game is also not very accommodating for people with disabilities. You can read more than a few threads on En Masse's website where people are asking for things as simple as a colorblind option, but they haven't been implemented into the game yet. There are also a few points where the physics breaks in the game or the world just disappears (but to be honest, most of them were when I spent 15min climbing that really tall mountain off in the distance that there was really no point to). There are also some repeatable quests in the game, and I didn't like that they would stay on your quest tracker hogging up space, and the only way to get rid of them is to permantly decline the quest. While these were minor issues for me, none of them ever got in my way of enjoying the game.

Why I'm not playing anymore:
What did get in my way of enjoying the game was the community. The chat in the game is set up in different categories (global, trade, party, etc.), but many people will use the chats interchangibly. While a minor inconvience, this isn't particularly an issue in-and-of itself. What is a problem is what ends up flooding the chat. It often feels like the chat is 85-90% composed of children just hitting puberty and discovering the internet for the first time. Vulgar texts, insults, sexual solicitations, and more flood almost every chat channel almost constantly, even occassionaly (but more often than you'd think) straying into threats of various abuses. The community's solution appears to be ignore this, but it's difficult when you have to ignore a little less than a quarter of your screen. You could also mute those players, but there are so many, it would be an unending process. It also makes it difficult to find parties to play with when soloing because players halfway expect you to be a jerk and will just ignore you. and the game's partying system is also flooded with these conversations, so it's almost impossible to find a party when you're under level 60.

Dealing with the community (and by dealing with, I mean putting up with their juvenile behavior while trying to ignore it) ended up sucking the fun out of the game for me. After a witnessing two individuals have a particularly vulgar conversation that lasted for over an hour, I found myself considering uninstalling the game. Personally, I have a policy that, if a game ever makes you think about uninstalling it, you should just do it. It's just a game, and there are others like it out there. Nothing is lost by walking away, so my quest for a good, immservise MMO will continue.

TL;DR: Game 7.5-8/10, but the community sucks and you sometimes want to uninstall.

reviewText:
There are a lot of good and bad things about this game, but I still recommend it overall.

Good things:
The combat is very fun to play for an mmorpg which is what wins this game over for me. The graphics to me are amazing for an mmo as well. Such detail is put into a lot of things, including your character's gear. Whenever you equip an item you notice everytime how it effects your characters appearance. It's also not a pay to win game. Very quick to queue for dungeons if you're a healer ;).

Bad things:
The game is ridiculously UNBALANCED. Gunner is pretty much the best class in whatever they do, and are the greatest dpsers. But because of that, some classes that could be so great are not worth playing because of the Reapers and Gunners just existing within the game. The game needs to nerf their overpowered classes. Also, the game has a very cluttered screen and the map and compass are not efficient. The map isn't to scale really, and it's not clear what you're doing or where to go for your quests. Just a very cluttered HUD in general that can be distracting, or makes you miss important announcements within the game or server. Crafting is pretty slow. You get stuck in the game a lot on stairs or other players, or on stuff that isn't even there causing you to jump tons of times to try to get to where you're going. Also when you do a quest that says it's for your level it lies because the quests don't actually really scale to your level. Dungeons can be unpleasant if you are stuck with people who don't know what they're doing; recommend to play it with friends.


If you get through the bad things this game is worth playing in my opinion.

reviewText:
I recommend Tera as an MMORPG as it is absolutely wonderful. I find it fun for both solo and group play, although soloing BAMs and Dungeons is definitely a challenge. There are certain things I dislike about the game as well, specifically the sexualized female characters (other than the Elin, although the community has sexualized them as well...), other than that, the story line is adequate, the amount of races and classes are nice, although I would like if some of the classes weren't gender or race specific.

Now for the heart of what I love about this game!
-Graphics - the graphics quality is amazing, and is the first thing that drew me to try Tera.
-Difficulty - being able to switch between different classes to try them out was pretty nice, I mean you had to recreate the character into a new class, but it was easy to do so if you wanted to swap. I lucked out with my love for the Archer class, it's a difficult class for solo play, but it has definitely improved my battle strategy for solo play. Such as watching other players in the world fight the BAMs to learn BAM attacks and strategize when I need to use my two main escapes in order to avoid damage. The archer class is pretty easy to learn, but it takes time to master, as you have so many combos and skills that you can switch around per enemy, certain skills are good for a quick getaway, others simply for hard damage output, etc. Soloing with this class is amazingly fun to me, but difficult and frustrating at times. On a team, the archer class, depending on the build, can be a I stand here and shoot constantly" type of play or a "I juggle aggro with other teammates and use my escapes to position close to the enemy for certain skills and far from the enemy for others"
-With any class

recommended: you need to understand how they can combo

reviewText:
I don't really enjoy MMOs. I've had a really bad experience with long grinds for one simple level up, impossible to reach end games, and terrible/dead communities.
Tera is an amazing game I'd definitely recommend, even though it has its cons - like any game.



Pros:
- Little to no grinding.
The hardest time I've ever had leveling was from 58 to 60, and that only took me a few days of casual play - maybe 30 min to an hour a day for 3 or 4 days.
- Great combat.
I hate point-&-click combat. Way too boring, and gear oriented. With an open combat system it requires skill, so that guy who spent $1000 to max absolutely everything out won't be able to kill you unless he puts time into learning how to play. So at the end of the day it doesn't come down to who can mash buttons the fastest.
- Awesome PvE.
Instance matching, hard dungeons, easy dungeons, solo dungeons, dungeons that require skill. It's all there.
- Awesome PvP.
I cannot get enough of Corsairs' Stronghold (a 20 v 20 Battleground in which defenders attempt to repel the enemy offensive).
- Fun early game.
When I first went through the game with my brother we had a blast. He chose a tank, and I chose a healer. We'd fight BAMs, do quests, and run dugeons, and we got from level 1 to level 40+ in 1 weekend.


Now here comes the cons:
- Elins.
Little girls in skimpy outfits. This doesn't need to exist.
- Popori
Fat little animal guys. They're all guys. They're all fat. They all look dumb.
The only redeeming quality they have is that I once saw a dog popori names barf. Tosher.
- Pedophiles.
I recall one morning logging on, execting another fun day playing Tera. Then I look in my chat, and read the elins thighs are so yummy!" I couldn't bring myself to play Tera for the rest of that day...
- Weeaboos... they're everywhere!
Honestly

reviewText:
Great AMMORPG with a unique combat system that no other game has been able to match to date. It's game-play is responsive and satisfying but suffers from a dated quest system and lacklustre storyline. Graphically, it still looks great despite only being powered by a modified Unreal 3 engine. There will be pop-ins, textures not loading until you are right next to them, and short view-distance. Their cash-store is loaded with costumes tailored to every kind of closet otaku out there (Yes, we are legion =-D). I'm ashamed to say I'm quite the whale for this game; to the magnitude of hundreds of CAD. Overall, this game is still one of my favorite games to come back to from time to time. Take my assessment with a grain of salt as I have invested heavily in it all the way from when it was released as a p2p game.

Here's a highlight of some of the enjoyable combat you will enjoy early on.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2QJrSXy-RfU

reviewText:
New to steam but the games' been out since 2012.  It was a bit too grindy when it was first released which killed off most of the casual audience - including myself.

The new gunner class and release on steam seems to have revived it - the new dungeon finder works great so you can skip questing entirely and just queue dungeons to level.

The main fun starts at level 65 dungeons are challenging but still fun.  Gear progression is there and there are hard modes once you've conquered the normal dungeons.

The community can be somewhat elitist but once you break in you'll understand why - still there's lot of nice people to help you.

Highly reccomend this game I'm having a lot more fun this time around.

reviewText:
Typical F2P MMORPG but very well polished unlike most and not P2W.
Questing, leveling, defeating BAMs, and completing dungeons isn't very challenging;
at some point it just becomes a daily routine/grind (take that as you may).
Players are rather toxic in PvP, namely Battle Grounds.

The biggest pro imo is that making money in this game is rather easy for new players
since there are so many ways of making gold in this game.

If you're looking for a decent F2P MMORPG to play, pick TERA. Overall it's nothing special, but it's still good.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic as a MMORPG but there are a few things to know about it...

- First, the art in this game is just unbelievably incredible, some of dungeons are really well designed, and the char customization is really cool.
- The advertising of the game is ALL about the action combat, so yeah, it is indeed really nice.
- It is F2P but its not -totally- P2W, which is a good thing I would say, since its almost a rule these days that F2P = P2W....
----
- The thing that I really hated on this game is: the main healer class (Priest) CANT DO DAMAGE, that is the signal of a REALLY BAD game design, I played as Priest and got to lvl 65 (max lvl) and I could still hold on, because on early game you don't really spend a lot of money, BUT once you get to enchanting high lvl gear, you TOTALLY need to up a DPS to farrm for money/enchanting resources...

And theres not a lot of people helping each other on early game, because the early game is really rushed by most players, so a healer will TOTALLY have to solo all the hard monsters... So you only should play healer if your friend won't mind helping you all the time on quests, or if you don't mind spending 10x the time it tooks to a DPS to kill a mob as healer

- This game has lots of bugs all over it, you will probably have to face a few that will make you have to restart the game.
- The new dungeon's bosses are totally copy and paste with a few new mechanics....
- If you are into crafting/alchemy prepare for the MASSIVE GRIND that it is to level your crafting levels.
- The late game alliance points system is good but it is a little bit too easy for trolling...
- If you're not into side quests, 90% of your time on the game will be just walking around, the main quests usually just make you travel the areas so you can get the side quests.


TL;DR: Good game (with the exception of healer players), its grindy and there is some annoying bugs, but its all worth it

reviewText:
I was going to write this review abit later when i have played all the characters to 65( max level) but now i have 5 characters all over 30 and 2 65s.

TL:DR all the way below

Let me start postively by the things I LOVED about this game:

- The Graphics : Really great and awesome for an MMO. Granted there are better but for a free to play MMO thats about 2 years old, this is amazing,

- The Gameplay/Combat : To be honest this is like the 70% of the reason why I play this game. It's just awesome. Very well executed true-action combat with great visuals on skills and animations.

- Costuming : Being a Korean MMO, if there's one thing they can never do wrong is costuming. Lots of flashy, sexy ..perverted *cough* and downright epic looking costumes and weapon skins. Some are free but most of them are paid. Understandable since they're just skins.

- Dungeons : There's a lot of dungeons for you to play... but i'll get into it later.

- Teamwork : There are dungeons where if one person fails, we all fail, requires true teamwork so great if you have a group of friends and teamspeak.

- Consumables : Unlike other games where buffs and damage boosters are optional, in TERA, they are downright awesome and you can see a SIGNIFICANT difference in damage and healing with/without using cosumables.


Alright so those are the six things I LOVED, now let's go to what I DON't LIKE:

- Yet another grindy MMO : Granted thats how MMOs are supposed to be, i still feel that they could've made it less grindy, especially for early levels. At 65 all you'll be doing is one dungeon 90% of your first days as max level to get your gear, or grinding BAM quests repeatdly.... and logging in NEXUS times to fight ur ♥♥♥ off to get that 900- 1.2k gold.

-P2W ?: ... not really but.., this is a tough one, and i might get a LOT of downvotes for this but i gotta be honest, i felt like it wasn't Pay to win either, but let's calculate EMP right now is atleast 12 gold , and if you downright spend 100$ which will gave u about 120k gold, You will be able to get your Schisma set all +12 ( which is like the decent standard for good parties to take you in) . Granted you can still make that but just a lot slower, and to be honest it doesn't really effect PVP. i should say it's more of Pay to Look Cool and Pay for Convinence.

- Game can become a routine : I played TERA 8 hours a day, along with dumping 60$ on the steam pack in order to get where i am which is +12 schisma gear. Sooner rather than later, you might * note i said might because if you joined a nice guild and made some really good friends you may be playing tera for the social aspect, in my case i didn't and i wasn't so the game becomes like a chore that i went through day by day.

My Overall rating for this game is 8.5/10 a great MMO thats worth your time and money, if you decide to spend.


TL: DR - Better than GW2 while being Free to Play. I  recommend this to any MMO, anime, action combat, cute characters, pantsu lover ... and pervs.

reviewText: Tera is one of the best anime MMORPGs. I played this game before it came to steam and cannot hide the awesome times i have had playing this master piece. It has great music that fits every moment, nice visual changes every time you equip new armor sets or weapons so that you don't feel as though you're putting on the same thing, a fun moving combat system (move around while attacking, using skills etc.) and a BIG pool of character creations (I literally spent 20 mins making my charcater). The quests are a bit lack luster having the same concept of the fetching quests or slay an amount of enemies. The menu can also get very confusing for players who are new to the MMORPG genre. I recommend this game to any gamers who want a thrilling and fun game to party up with friends to take on raids or fight in PvP. Would get into it again if I had some motivation :P 9/10\n\n-Andde

reviewText: Ok let me start out be saying very good gameplay. The best combat system I have ever seen, you have to be skillful at this game to succeed. Tera is not optimized what so ever, even with a beastly computer that can play Star Citizen's Arena Commander mod on very high graphics with no problems. Tera on most computers will run smooth and then all of a suddenly go from 59fps of smooth gameplay down to a 4 second cycle of 0 fps. To get gear in this game is very difficult without flat out spending real cash to buy EMP items and selling said items in game for gold. This is because there is a cap to how many PvE and PvP points you can earn pre a day/week. I hit the weekly cap within 2 days and have to wait 5 to 4 more days for the weekly reset to earn more. All timegates in this game can be overturned by spending real life cash on this game. This game is very pay to win, so if you can deal with that part of the game it's a very good game, IMHO the best Fantasy Action MMORPG on the market.

reviewText:
5/5/2015 Is the day my life was gone.

This game is a 8/10 not many problems and its a ton of fun. There's 3 different currencies - Gold,Fashion Coupons,EMP

Gold- Just like any game the default currency
Fashion Coupon- you farm mobs to get these tickets to get costumes/skins for your weapons
EMP- The paid currency to get costumes,skins,scrolls, and mounts. (Not P2W)

The end game isn't amazing but its not bad, There's alot of things to do if you join a semi/populated server and join a decent size guild you can do GVG's and etc.

There's an upcomming patch that will be adding alot of new stuff coming July 7th 2015

reviewText:
A typical day in TERA:

1. Go to local town.
2. Callout to random people for someone who would sell themselves to do menial labour for us.
3. About 5 people enlist and join our party.
4. We slay many mobs.
5. We dance around a fireplace.
6. We screw around with emotes.
7. It is 4.50am irl.
8. I sit down in a corner and announce my leave.
9. Everyone cri.
10. I cry myself to sleep.
11. Rinse and repeat steps 1-10.

This is the first mmorpg I actually think is worth my time, everything is amazing, graphics, fighting, pvp, pve, fighting, more fighting, did I mention fighting?

reviewText:
ive played this game since gunner first came out and all i have to say to new players is this..

#1-Your server: if you want to be able to pk or have to fight off pkers choose a PVP server(i used mount tyrannas), if you are just here for dungeons and battleground pvp matchmaking choose a pve server (Tempest Reach reccomended)

#2- First class:  if this is your first mmorpg, i sould recommend that you start out with gunner or archer. that are really solid classes to play

#3- FIND A GUILD!:  this game is 100% more fun to play with friends to quest with, pvp with and to just talk in general

#4 leveling: like most mmorpgs Dungeons are the fastest way to level, but may get boring at times, so quests are the way to go if your loking for a solid experience.

#5 MAX lvl (65) when you get max leveling a would recommend doing all 3 of these things
-find a guild with an allince
-find someone to explain masterworking,awakening, getting +15, and crystals
-look up gear levels (pvp i start with deviate, pve i start with fulminate)
#6 HAVE FUN!

reviewText:
Are you sick of MMO's where all you have to do hit a sequence of buttons?
Are you tired of simply locking on to your foes, and praying to RNGesus that your attacks hit?

TERA fixes all of this, and actually makes combat fun.

In this game, you actually AIM all of your attacks, be it ranged projectiles or just sword swings, and hitting or missing actually depends on whether you hit or miss. This also applies to the enemies' attacks, so to help with this, you have the ability to dodge roll, teleport, or block, depending on your class. In the end, it actually plays more like a third person action game.

Another thing... It's ACTUALLY free to play.

It is the best form of a F2P system. You can't pay to win. Buying items is restricted to aesthetics, such as costumes and mounts, as well as convenience items to assist with crafting or traveling. Most of these items are sold by players for game currency anyway, so if you just NEED those items for whatever reason, you can still get them.

The game also looks pretty good. Of course its not the BEST looking game around, but for an mmo, it does a good job trying to bring the mmo genre into the modern age of graphics.

If you like any regular MMO, you'll like this more. I completely recommend it.

reviewText:
TERA is an incredible MMO experience for both players new to the MMO genre and and Veterans as old as WoW. Despite being such an old game, it still has the quality you'd expect from a high-quality KMMO made today.

One of the best aspects of TERA - if not the best aspect - is the incredible Action Combat. Both the community and the developers brag and boast about it's amazing combative system, which is completely justified. It's combat alone ranks it one of the highest-tier MMO you could possible play in the market right and the foreseeable future. It's PvP is intense and very rewarding for the high amount of skill it takes, and the PvE boast a high diversity in bosses, dungeons, and even the general mobs. The new Gunner class is exceptionally well made, and very fun to play.

The second aspect of TERA that makes it so wonderful is the incredible open world. TERA is a very big game, with a very big world to explore. If you wanted, you could walk from one end of a continent from the other without experiencing a single loading screen to cut off your fun, all the while trying out that incredible combat that becomes incredible diverse later on.

TERA is also a pretty game. It certainly feels like a game from 2014-15, instead of 2011, when it actually came out in Japan, or 2012, when it was released in the United States. The graphics are incredible and if you've got a really good PC, you can really enjoy playing TERA at it's finest. The view from certain areas can be breathtaking, and the best is that it goes on forever for you to explore.

In this incredible open-world experience, you have a choice from seven different races, all having different traits that help them along their path to greatness. Choose from 10 different classes, which includes the new Gunner class. And when you get to level 65 and are ready to do whatever it is you do, just remember;

Elin are your waifus and Global Chat is amazing.

reviewText:
Best MMORPG I have ever played in my life in MANY aspects.
1. Gameplay
Most MMORPGS you click on a monster once and you press your skills. In Tera however, you do something completely different and unique; you aim at the monster and preform your attacks manually with a series of left clicks and right clicks. If you trigger a combo move you press space, and hell, its satisfying when you get a combo right on. All of this is done with manual aiming. This makes it VERY unique and fun for ranged classes like Gunner. Next is dodging attacks. In most MMORPGS, you stand still and take the hit, or use some ability to block. In this you have to time dodges or counters, where you character litterally steps out the way of the attack or does a motion to counter the attack, a dodge or counter can also lead to a very satisfying combo.
2. First Impressions
This game nails first impressions. When you first start, you verse giant monsters, your in an interesting quest line that gave me the feels and the monsters have attack makers so you can pull of impressive dodges or counters. After completing this quest you ride a pegusus to the mainland. During the flight the mythical horse flies over the entire starting area, it looks beautiful, ok, then it goes in a gate and then you see the mainland for the first time, from the sky and its BREATHTAKING. On high graphics, it looked so beautiful! At that moment I already fell in love with this game.
3. Community
Ok, im a weeaboo, at least in the eyes of the internet in general. In Tera, everyones a weeaboo, the community is very fitting for those who love Anime or Japanese Culture. The game itself even knows that since the description of the Elin race is a waifu" and we can all tell they are Kawaii Lolis too. I think i made more friends in this game than in real life.

And this is my first ever legit review. So if i screwed anything over don't be to harsh please. Thanks."

reviewText:
REVIEW:
A pretty nice F2P MMORPG, especially if you're looking for an excelling combat system, some stunning graphics, and massive-like bosses. A ton of fun to play.

PROS:
- Combat system actually requires some skill.
- Stunning graphics.
- Ton of fun to play with friends!
- PvP is pretty challenging!
- Huge bosses, tons of customizations, and a lot of skills!
- IT'S FREE!!!

CONS:
- Gets somehow boring if you go solo all the way, so be sure to team up!
- Combat, after some levels, is actually nothing more than grinding for EXP. The fun comes in when you get new gear or new skills!
- Quests are pretty 'generic', like go get 5 of these or, kill 3 of these, etc...
- Real-life currency is likely to be used for getting some boosters, etc, but this doesn't give you that much of an advantage.

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT?
The answer's yes: it's free, it's nice, and it's awesome, so why not?

reviewText: Tera is one of the few MMOs that don't make me groan whenever I see an update. Generally, I'm used to every update wanting in my wallet; while Tera does offer cash options for their events, you can also achieve everything with enough effort or luck. I've put a total of $20 in this game, and that was unnecessary. What I find to be the best part, events are usually well-rounded, so that new and older users can do them despite level. It's true that the top level users get more events, but they're not the only ones that get to participate. Also, out of all of the MMOs I've played, Tera has one of the best communities, it still sucks because it's an MMO community, but the community doesn't suck nearly as much as others.

reviewText: Ok let me start out be saying very good gameplay. The best combat system I have ever seen, you have to be skillful at this game to succeed. Tera is not optimized what so ever, even with a beastly computer that can play Star Citizen's Arena Commander mod on very high graphics with no problems. Tera on most computers will run smooth and then all of a suddenly go from 59fps of smooth gameplay down to a 4 second cycle of 0 fps. To get gear in this game is very difficult without flat out spending real cash to buy EMP items and selling said items in game for gold. This is because there is a cap to how many PvE and PvP points you can earn pre a day/week. I hit the weekly cap within 2 days and have to wait 5 to 4 more days for the weekly reset to earn more. reviewText:
I've got more than 60 hours in this game, and I really enjoy it, but I'm sad to say I won't be playing it again.

First the pros:
The art is beautiful in this game, especially for an MMO. Honestly, that's what first grabbed my attention for the game. I also like that the game is just as easy to play solo as it is with others. I enjoyed the combat system, think the UI is pretty efficient, and liked the crafting system. The characters and quests have a bit more thought put into them than your typical MMO, and that's pretty cool to. It's also fairly easy to get started in the game, and you can jump into it quickly, or take your time and look around. I also liked that, while you can certainly pay to get some pretty cool extras, I never felt like it was a pay-to-win game (that said, I have not played the PvP aspect of the game).

Then the cons:
There were only a few things I didn't like in this game. The partying system is not friendly to players who are new to MMOs. I had a friend play with me, and, when I wasn't there, they had to google how to get some things done just to basic stuff in chat. You also can't tell what channel someone is on, even if they're in your party, although this can be worked around with a bit of communication. The game is also not very accommodating for people with disabilities. You can read more than a few threads on En Masse's website where people are asking for things as simple as a colorblind option, but they haven't been implemented into the game yet. There are also a few points where the physics breaks in the game or the world just disappears (but to be honest, most of them were when I spent 15min climbing that really tall mountain off in the distance that there was really no point to). There are also some repeatable quests in the game, and I didn't like that they would stay on your quest tracker hogging up space, and the only way to get rid of them is to permantly decline the quest. While these were minor issues for me, none of them ever got in my way of enjoying the game.

Why I'm not playing anymore:
What did get in my way of enjoying the game was the community. The chat in the game is set up in different categories (global, trade, party, etc.), but many people will use the chats interchangibly. While a minor inconvience, this isn't particularly an issue in-and-of itself. What is a problem is what ends up flooding the chat. It often feels like the chat is 85-90% composed of children just hitting puberty and discovering the internet for the first time. Vulgar texts, insults, sexual solicitations, and more flood almost every chat channel almost constantly, even occassionaly (but more often than you'd think) straying into threats of various abuses. The community's solution appears to be ignore this, but it's difficult when you have to ignore a little less than a quarter of your screen. You could also mute those players, but there are so many, it would be an unending process. It also makes it difficult to find parties to play with when soloing because players halfway expect you to be a jerk and will just ignore you. and the game's partying system is also flooded with these conversations, so it's almost impossible to find a party when you're under level 60.

Dealing with the community (and by dealing with, I mean putting up with their juvenile behavior while trying to ignore it) ended up sucking the fun out of the game for me. After a witnessing two individuals have a particularly vulgar conversation that lasted for over an hour, I found myself considering uninstalling the game. Personally, I have a policy that, if a game ever makes you think about uninstalling it, you should just do it. It's just a game, and there are others like it out there. Nothing is lost by walking away, so my quest for a good, immservise MMO will continue.

TL;DR: Game 7.5-8/10, but the community sucks and you sometimes want to uninstall.

reviewText:
TERA isn't much unlike any other MMORPG, but the way it delivers it's content is satisfying. Mainly focused on combat, TERA offers exciting gameplay for any player, and with new content coming in regularly, it promises a rewarding experience for those willing to invest their time.. Definately worth every dollar I spent on it. ($0)

The combat in TERA is fast-paced and rewarding, regardless of class or role. I wouldn't call it a 'unique experience', but it feels very solid and demands your attention. Even the healing roles are given a lot of consideration.
The one downside that I have found is that there isn't much in the ways of ingame career options, so if your main focus in an MMO is the mercantile side of things, you may want to find another game.

Overall, TERA deserves to go on your top 5 list if you're looking for a new game to waste your life in. It's a good game, and it's free. Nothing's better than free.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has it's issues. PvE is fairly dead this patch, as is the economy, not many ways to make money these days, and PvP has never been a huge part of the game so the community for it isn't that big. Lore is and always has been pretty poor quality, in my opinion. Not to mention leveling is so quick and brainlessly easy that you get people at end game who are still completely clueless.

Other issues lie with how the game runs. It's great if you have a top tier computer, but even then you'll find issues. Small UI bugs once in a blue moon, disconnecting some days more than should be normal. Servers just aren't always stable. Especially during events, when the number of accounts logged into game are higher.

But where it falls short one can still finds redeeming qualities. PvE, even during the dead points can still be fun with friends. Same with PvP. The combat system in TERA is by far one of the most enjoyable I've crossed in any MMO. Graphics, if you like the artstyle, are wonderful. The environment is filled with scenery worth taking the time to stop and admire. Character creation, while not the best available, is still better than a lot of MMOs out there, offering a wide variety of options for personalizing your player character. And the cosmetics? Addicting. So be careful with that one! They just love to lock the best ones behind rng. But when you're a free to play game, it's not hard to picture where most of their income comes from.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic as a MMORPG but there are a few things to know about it...

- First, the art in this game is just unbelievably incredible, some of dungeons are really well designed, and the char customization is really cool.
- The advertising of the game is ALL about the action combat, so yeah, it is indeed really nice.
- It is F2P but its not -totally- P2W, which is a good thing I would say, since its almost a rule these days that F2P = P2W....
----
- The thing that I really hated on this game is: the main healer class (Priest) CANT DO DAMAGE, that is the signal of a REALLY BAD game design, I played as Priest and got to lvl 65 (max lvl) and I could still hold on, because on early game you don't really spend a lot of money, BUT once you get to enchanting high lvl gear, you TOTALLY need to up a DPS to farrm for money/enchanting resources...

And theres not a lot of people helping each other on early game, because the early game is really rushed by most players, so a healer will TOTALLY have to solo all the hard monsters... So you only should play healer if your friend won't mind helping you all the time on quests, or if you don't mind spending 10x the time it tooks to a DPS to kill a mob as healer

- This game has lots of bugs all over it, you will probably have to face a few that will make you have to restart the game.
- The new dungeon's bosses are totally copy and paste with a few new mechanics....
- If you are into crafting/alchemy prepare for the MASSIVE GRIND that it is to level your crafting levels.
- The late game alliance points system is good but it is a little bit too easy for trolling...
- If you're not into side quests, 90% of your time on the game will be just walking around, the main quests usually just make you travel the areas so you can get the side quests.


TL;DR: Good game (with the exception of healer players), its grindy and there is some annoying bugs, but its all worth it

reviewText: Quite honestly, I think this is a great MMORPG. It's fluid in what you can do and how you control your character. The graphics are amazing, but you REALLY need a fast internet and good graphics card. After level ~40, everything seems to get redundant. Quests that are pretty much the same. I'm trying to learn how to make weapons and craft items, but it doesn't seem as simple as it does in Runescape (yes, the Runescape days). I wished some features like that were easier to do, but you can get discouraged really easily. However, the game is much more than crafting. You may never craft in your game and that's fine. I think it's just super fun. I wish there were more cool items available to free players and not so much pay with money" stuff. Other than that

reviewText:
ive played this game since gunner first came out and all i have to say to new players is this..

#1-Your server: if you want to be able to pk or have to fight off pkers choose a PVP server(i used mount tyrannas), if you are just here for dungeons and battleground pvp matchmaking choose a pve server (Tempest Reach reccomended)

#2- First class:  if this is your first mmorpg, i sould recommend that you start out with gunner or archer. that are really solid classes to play

#3- FIND A GUILD!:  this game is 100% more fun to play with friends to quest with, pvp with and to just talk in general

#4 leveling: like most mmorpgs Dungeons are the fastest way to level, but may get boring at times, so quests are the way to go if your loking for a solid experience.

#5 MAX lvl (65) when you get max leveling a would recommend doing all 3 of these things
-find a guild with an allince
-find someone to explain masterworking,awakening, getting +15, and crystals
-look up gear levels (pvp i start with deviate, pve i start with fulminate)
#6 HAVE FUN!

reviewText:
Free to play, not pay to win.
sold.
Really the only thing i have noticed abotu paying for stuff is you can get costumes a lot easier, and you level up a lot faster.

More about leveling up: It is already really fast.  This game tries to get you to the end game content quick.

Fun game, good graphics, good story.  Combat very unique (i am a fan of tab targeting, this is more skill / aim based)
PvP doesn't seem to be as big a deal (no arenas, only BGs and PKing)

If you have read or wathced Sword Art Online, chances are you'll like this game.  Combat of this game reminds me of the anime.

Fun game, not very time consuming if you want to just log in and start playing, and it is very easy to drop for 6 months and come back to.

As a long time wow player, i must say that i like it more than wow

reviewText:
I had a guildmate with an end-game gear (before knockout patch), still got owned easily by the boss when he went to solo the boss while in party.  So party composition is important in order to complete the dungeon runs(1 Tank, 1 Healer, 3 DPS). You must also know the mechanics of the dungeons or else you will be dead for 9999 times.

Also it is not a P2W game, all you have to spend with your cash are costumes, mounts, and some enhancements and all this cash shop purchases are tradeable and can be sold to trade broker (trading house in other MMOs) until you use it.

The only downside of this game are the gender-locked classes, specially the new update released last week that had a human female locked brawler class. I'm fine with the race lock but seriously the gender lock??! I mean how many recent classes are already female locked? Gunner (Elf or Castanic Female Only), Reaper (Elin Only, and Elin is a Loli Female Race), and now the Brawler (Human Female Only). It would be awesome to create a male brawler but damn. I bet the next new class would also be gender locked to female. %$!#&!!


8/10 It would have been awesome if only those gender locked thingy would be removed.

TERA, in my opinion, shows its strengths in several ways: one of them are the classes: very defined and whose gameplay as decisive and marked the gaming experience becomes something totally different depending on the selected class. I tried all classes, not races, and each approach offers diversity that we require a game of this nature. Undoubtedly, another important feature is the combat; As you know, TERA goes beyond the concept of focus other traditional MMORPG and forces us to target our characters in the direction we're going to hit, cast a spell, etc., provided with a central point of looking at screen. At the same time, the characters are real physics, so bother and obstruct. This is crucial in group meetings, instances, bosses, etc ?? A portion also are policy issues that I could prove in depth.

reviewText:
Pretty awesome game for free. Unfortunatley the engine is bland and outdated.

PvP desyncs like crazy and is nothing but a slideshow no matter how much you try to optimize it for your system, and don't bother telling me my system is the problem because I can play any 2016 game on ultra w/o issue, Black Desert? flawless aside from the occasional internet and server issues.

PvE is alright, Big ♥♥♥ Monster seem a lot easier apposed to before steam adopted the game. The aggro system is a bit confusing and with all the newer characters, tanks seem pretty useless until end game. So lancers, warrior, and berserkers enjoy the walking sim until late game.

Crafting... Well it's your typical WoW crafting.

Social depends on what server you're on. RP/PvE if you want to meet decent people (experience may very) and PvP if you want to be treated like dirt.

Classes - well I enjoy looking like a beast, tank, don't want to mess with this guy, type of guy. So male characters are strict to the original typical classes, but with all the new content is based mainly around female and the lolli sort and it aint my cup of tea. Devs are biased as all hell so be warned.

All in All, I would recommend this game, but only if you plan to play with others. If you just go solo you will get bored extremely fast and uninstall before you know it.

reviewText:
Played the game long enough off of steam to run a few characters into endgame, came back to the steam version to find some seriously troubling Tera Store items. One of the things I valued most about this game was its fantasy aesthetic, world, and lore.

When they started selling swim trunks and bikinis, I wasn't very pleased, but I could live with it.
When they sold lingerie and silk underwear I wasn't thrilled, but hey fanservice and 'RP' will happen.
When they added Pixel Art styled weapon skins, my immersion was a little shaken.

Now they sell mounts that are sports cars.
Now they sell clothes that include snap back hats and rapper chains, along with gaudy wristwatches on each arm.
Now they sell boomboxes you can wear on your back.

The devs or marketting department have seriously lost the plot.
I don't foresee myself getting back into this game ever again.
Also, the mid-to-highbie population of my server is 9/10ths elin. Until now, I'd never had a problem with that race.

reviewText: I've played Tera for almost 2 years now and I can still say this is the best free to play MMO out there, currently. No other game compares to it's style of combat. The questing is fun and the BAMs are always a blast to fight. I've reached mid-game, played the Reaper, and got my Gunner to lvl 60+. The events are fun and rewarding. I've been using EnMasse's client up until just now and I've also bought the summer pack.

reviewText: While I don't have this game on Steam, I have countless hours in Tera. I can easily say it is the best MMORPG I have played yet, with a mystic as my main character it gives me everything I have always wanted. If your looking for a good, fun MMORPG, then stop looking and download Tera. Even if you dont like it, its free! So whats the harm?\nThe game doesn't push you at all to buy things with real money, almost anything is available to buy with in game money at a tradebroker as long as you have enough gold! True action combat style, so you can dodge stuff if your fast enough, a class for each need, each with different abilities to help eachother out, 2 great support classes if you are into that like I am, 2 tanks, and 3 (I think) classes for pure damage. If this is your first MMO, you will love it, and if you are experienced, it may be different from some others but you will come to love it as well.
